oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Farmer standing next to TVA power lines
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A large transmission tower and transmission lines. A farmer stands at the base of the tower. Caption on reverse reads: "Great transmission lines criss-cross the Tennessee Valley to bring TVA electric power to war industries and to 130 municipal and cooperative electric systems which serve 575,000 customers. Since 1933, the proportion of farms with electric service has increased from one in 28 to one in four."

The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) was created by the Tennessee Valley Authority Act, which President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed into law in 1933. One of the purposes of the TVA was to provide cheap electricity for rural electrification.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee; Tennessee Valley Authority--History; Rural electrification--Government policy--United States; Rural electrification--Tennessee; Rural electrification--United States--History
Energy; Electric lines
